path_1.title: Hereditary (2018)
path_1.feeling: The slow-burn occult spiral and grief-soaked atmosphere got under my skin.

path_1.title: Wind River (2017)
path_1.feeling: Bleak, focused investigation with isolating tension that kept me engaged.

path_1.title: Thelma & Louise (1991)
path_1.feeling: The escalating stakes and fierce bond made the ride gripping and poignant.

path_1.title: More (1998)
path_1.feeling: A melancholic, inventive sci-fi parable that lingers with a bittersweet aftertaste.

path_1.title: Sick of Myself (2022)
path_1.feeling: Sharp and mean, but the narcissistic satire left me more irritated than thrilled.

path_1.title: Last of Sheila, The (1973)
path_1.feeling: A deliciously twisty yacht-game of secrets that scratches my mystery itch.

path_1.title: Mommy Dead and Dearest (2017)
path_1.feeling: Disturbing and compelling, if presented a bit straightforwardly.

path_1.title: Rebecca (1940)
path_1.feeling: Gothic mood and jealous undercurrents worked, even if the pacing feels stately.

path_1.title: The Mortuary Collection (2020)
path_1.feeling: Stylish, macabre fun with a satisfying wraparound sting.

path_1.title: Buried Alive (1990)
path_1.feeling: Pulpy and engaging, though it carries that TV-movie thinness.

path_1.title: Halloween (1978)
path_1.feeling: Iconic, spare suspense that works even if it’s more straightforward than I prefer.

path_1.title: District 9 (2009)
path_1.feeling: Inventive world-building and body-horror beats, but the action tilt dulled my attachment.

path_1.title: Aurora (2012)
path_1.feeling: A haunting blend of mind-link romance and sci-fi mystery that stuck with me.

path_1.title: I Am Mother (2019)
path_1.feeling: Taut chamber sci-fi with moral puzzles that kept me guessing.

path_1.title: The Guilty (2018)
path_1.feeling: Minimalist, nerve-jangling and fueled by imagination.

path_1.title: The Body (2012)
path_1.feeling: Slick, twisty morgue mystery that hits my sweet spot.

path_1.title: Misery (1990)
path_1.feeling: Claustrophobic obsession with great escalation and tension.

path_1.title: Dark Harbor (1999)
path_1.feeling: Moody and perverse, intriguing even if the pull wavers.

path_1.title: Tür, Die (Door, The) (2009)
path_1.feeling: A clever second-chance premise with dark, satisfying turns.

path_1.title: Manhattan Night (2016)
path_1.feeling: Sexy noir trappings with enough intrigue, if not fully gripping.

path_1.title: Dorothy Mills (2008)
path_1.feeling: Atmospheric and intriguing, though the payoff is a bit wobbly.

path_1.title: Match Point (2005)
path_1.feeling: Cold and calculated in a way I admired more than I felt.

path_1.title: Anguish (Angustia) (1987)
path_1.feeling: Meta-horror that’s conceptually fun more than truly chilling.

path_1.title: A Good Woman Is Hard to Find (2019)
path_1.feeling: Gritty, tense, and satisfying in its fierce turnabout.

path_1.title: Fish Tank (2009)
path_1.feeling: Strong performances, but this flavor of social realism rarely hooks me.

path_1.title: Final Destination (2000)
path_1.feeling: High-concept set pieces are fun even if the teen slasher sheen dates it.

path_1.title: Revanche (2008)
path_1.feeling: Somber, patient crime drama that engages more intellectually than viscerally.

path_1.title: The Lighthouse (2019)
path_1.feeling: Hypnotic and unsettling, though the art-house abrasion kept me at arm’s length.

path_5.feeling: Isolated hostility and fractured-identity dread hit a solid psychological groove.

path_5.title: Match Point (2005)
path_5.feeling: Ambition, lust, and a cold-blooded crime spiral provide a chilly charge.

path_5.title: Anguish (Angustia) (1987)
path_5.feeling: Reality-splitting, ocular-obsessive horror gives a queasy, off-kilter menace.

path_5.title: A Good Woman Is Hard to Find (2019)
path_5.feeling: Desperate-mom vigilance and street-level stakes make for gritty tension.

path_5.title: Fish Tank (2009)
path_5.feeling: Raw, bleak coming-of-age volatility holds me without a mystery spine.

path_5.title: Final Destination (2000)
path_5.feeling: Fun fatalism and set-piece dread more concept than deep chill.

path_5.title: Revanche (2008)
path_5.feeling: Somber, morally tangled crime and vengeance simmer with slow-burn tension.

path_5.title: The Lighthouse (2019)
path_5.feeling: Salt-soaked madness and claustrophobic mind games fit, even if the artiness keeps me slightly removed.

path_5.title: Hereditary (2018)
path_5.feeling: Familial doom and occult dread push the kind of psychological terror I crave.

path_5.title: Wind River (2017)
path_5.feeling: Bleak, wintry manhunt with moral weight and mounting dread hits my crime-thriller sweet spot.

path_5.title: Thelma & Louise (1991)
path_5.feeling: Fugitive spiral with tragic momentum and gritty stakes keeps me tense and invested.

path_5.title: More (1998)
path_5.feeling: Inventive melancholic sci‑fi fable with a chilling moral sting and mood I respond to.

path_5.title: Sick of Myself (2022)
path_5.feeling: Caustic narcissism spiral intrigues, though the satirical comedy tone keeps me at a remove.

path_5.title: Last of Sheila, The (1973)
path_5.feeling: Cruel gamesmanship and layered clues make for a twisty, satisfying whodunit.

path_5.title: Mommy Dead and Dearest (2017)
path_5.feeling: A grim, manipulative true-crime saga with moral tension that grips throughout.

path_5.title: Rebecca (1940)
path_5.feeling: Gothic paranoia and jealous obsession work, even if the romantic trappings soften the edge.

path_5.title: The Mortuary Collection (2020)
path_5.feeling: Stylish, macabre anthology fun with enough menace and morality tales to satisfy.

path_5.title: Buried Alive (1990)
path_5.feeling: Pulp TV-movie intrigue delivers simple, grim satisfaction despite its modest sheen.

path_5.title: Halloween (1978)
path_5.feeling: Lean, relentless stalking dread and spare craft build a nervy, effective chill.

path_5.title: District 9 (2009)
path_5.feeling: Body-horror transformation and moral rot lend real bite beyond the sci‑fi spectacle.

path_5.title: Aurora (2012)
path_5.feeling: Intimate mind‑link sci‑fi with longing and paranoia—haunting, tender, and thrilling.

path_5.title: I Am Mother (2019)
path_5.feeling: Contained sci‑fi tension and shifting trust dynamics scratch my paranoid itch.

path_5.title: The Guilty (2018)
path_5.feeling: Phone‑booth style pressure cooker with moral ambiguity that tightens like a vise.

path_5.title: The Body (2012)
path_5.feeling: Sleek, twisty morgue mystery that keeps me guessing and savoring the reveals.

path_5.title: Misery (1990)
path_5.feeling: Claustrophobic captivity and obsessive menace make for exquisitely tense, character‑driven terror.

path_5.title: Dark Harbor (1999)
path_5.feeling: Seamy, rain‑soaked deception with sexual undercurrents and a nasty little twist.

path_5.title: Tür, Die (Door, The) (2009)
path_5.feeling: Grief‑driven, reality‑bending thriller with a moody, fatalistic pull I enjoy.

path_5.title: Manhattan Night (2016)
path_5.feeling: Slick tabloid noir with sex and blackmail, but the tension feels a bit canned.

path_5.feeling: Gritty coming‑of‑age despair holds me, even without a mystery spine.
